Hello Rohit,

On 08/19/2017 11:32 PM, Rohit Yadav wrote:
> Thanks @sl0 <https://github.com/sl0>, can you re-publish the source file
> under Apache License 2.0 in your repo that we can use, or send to us as
> a pull request?

You just not want to use the whole package, just part of it. And Daan
asked me th have it with Apache License. I agreed and he has changed in
your repo and I agreed again.

Is this not enough for you? I've put GPL on my sources to prevent them
from been put into a commerial cloesed source project legally. The
inheritance priciple of GPL is very important for me.

FYI: As I worked a long time on it and then continued to have it in
Debian, I'm afraid of changing the license to any other. And today it is
contained in the Debian stretch release, if you like, take it as a
debian package as an external component?

I totally agree to have parts of my iptables-converter within Apache
Cloudstack relicensed to Apache License, but I would be very unhappy to
change GPL on my sources at github, because I'm afraid I have to leave
the Debian Friends...

Thanks for reading, kind regards from Cologne, Germany.
Thank you in advance for any response.

Johannes
(sl0)

Hello Johannes ( @sl0 ),
Thank you for replying. Sorry for the confusion, I'm not requesting you to move towards a new license but dual-license your work, i.e. both your GPL and Apache license. It would be best if you do that in your repository so we can point to your work in case of any issues. One way to do that is to include the Apache License in your repo's root folder and include the Apache license on all the file headers like it's been done in this PR. You may, for example, look at https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/tree/master and others who have adopted a dual-license approach. Thanks a lot for the conversation and your swift reply.

Regards, Rohit (@rhtyd).
